comments.commentBody: Cruz is a demagogue. He uses his intelligence to spout nonsense and make trouble, consistently. If you think one of his beliefs is that he can say anything he wants to get attention, then I guess he's true to his opinion of himself. But honest - not hardly. Egotism plus ambition does not equal honesty.
Bingo.

Steve...excellent  post, thank you for facts on "temp teachers making a minimum wage who is likely looking for another job. Is that worth your money?" Good point. Somebody is getting rich on this scheme. ...

Ahem. "Temp teacher" is the wrong description of adjuncts teaching at the college level. Yes, many of us only have M.A. degrees, which qualify us as lecturers as opposed to tenure-track professorships. We get to teach in community colleges and freshman courses when enrollment demands extra coverage, usually in the fall and winter terms, in the core-requirement courses, and in the remedial courses (which unfortunately have become permanent offerings at the freshman level). But cases I have known about, the quality of teaching often surpasses the work of professors. For one thing, "We try harder." For another, we are generally as well-prepared as the average doctoral t.a. Also, given the support and respect of the department, we do have academic freedom to teach in creative ways and we often enjoy professional recognition. Finally, we are so darn happy to actually be in a college classroom teaching, rather than pounding the pavement in the stultifying perpetual job search, that we find the work personally rewarding, regardless of the pay.
As for the federal government dropping the gavel--it is the federal loan guarantee to the schools that has sweetened the deal, just as it has with FHA and VA mortgage loans. That the banksters, student loan-jobbers, and the schools themselves have taken cynical advantage of a well-meaning program, merely indicates it is definitely time to rethink the student loan scenario.

In my view, the universities are the main culprits in this student debt story. Universities have detoured from their professed social mission of teaching, research, and service into a corporate-like business structure. As such, university administrations have become obese in their administrative budgets, resulting in CEO-like salaries, and moreover have become reckless in their spending: posh dorms, gourmet cafeterias, new sports stadiums, rockstar coaches and players, and always some new construction project.

Why? And for what? They claim they have to keep ahead of their peer schools, and that "everyone else is doing it." Such an "arms race" has consistently resulted tuition raises, and furthermore has resulted in a cannibalization of their faculty. At present, roughly 70% of university courses are taught by adjunct faculty earning roughly $2500 per course.

Think about that for a moment: If your son or daughter is paying $40,000 a year (or more) to go to x-University, the majority of the courses they will take will be taught by a temp teacher making a minimum wage who is likely looking for another job. Is that worth your money?

The current university model is unsustainable, and creating a potential economic crisis. If university administrators are not willing to look themselves in the mirror and realize the cold facts that they are enriching themselves at the expense of putting a whole generation of young people in debt, then the federal government needs drop the gavel.

I read a book a few years ago which discussed BBC English. It seems teh Government decided that all the English people should speak exactly alike so they prepared a list pf words and how they were to be produced by the speaker. It didn't work. You needn't be Profesor Higgins to hear the numerous accents still heard just in the London area.  I was born in New York City and when younger I spoke with a New York  accent but I have lived in the South since I was12. (I'm 62)  When I speak to New Yorkers they say I have a Southern accent while Southeners hear a New York accent. As long as they can understand me I don't care what they hear.
She is originally from Louisville, KY - could that be part of it since I've noticed that some southern women speak rather like that.

I tend to think that the standard American English accent is that used by broadcasters, which to my ear is the Western CT - Northern CA accent. I'm always amused then one says to another person "you have an accent" to which maybe the correct, if cheeky , response is "no, you're the one with the accent."

While I've lived in the South for many years I still have my Western CT "accent" but enjoy hearing many Southern women speak with what I consider to be a gentle accent, and I always counsel Southerners to use the riposte above as something of an antidote to the way they're unfairly lampooned in the voice media, since I know that, while some of them may not be as well educated as many Northerners, there's no lack of smarts in these parts, and a Southern accent is a potent secret weapon to have when dealing with some New Yorker who thinks s/he's fast talking a Southerner.

On the subject of accents generally, what about the idea that the standard English accent worldwide is defined by the accent used by the greatest number of English speakers. 20 years ago that meant that the standard English accent was that used in New Delhi, and I imagine that an updated look wouldn't change that.

The federal loans I took out for my children's college education is at 8%, not 6.8% The lower rate applies if the student borrows, not the parent.

I agree that it is unconscionable for the government to lend money to me for my children's education at 8% and lend to the fraudster bankers at approximately zero percent. Bravo Elizabeth Warren!

My third child is attending university in Canada, where costs are about half of US levels and educational levels are higher.

Greg, US:

So people who don't like to be frisked should be considered suspicious?

No David, proxies are substitutes for instrumental measurements.  Read the link.  The formally-know-as thinks temperature measurements are a proxy for what is going on with the climate.  But, they ARE what is going on with the climate, by definition.  What we measure is what the climate is really truly really doing. Don't get muddled.  The existence of measurement error is not the same as having no measurements at all.

BTW, Samuel L Jackson as a Jedi has to be what's pictured in the dictonary under "miscast." But it was more than enough for yesterday. For the record, I'm done until tomorrow. SamE old SamE old.

I searched for a coherent thread of ideas or even a coherent idea in this article and could not find one.  The author seems to acknowledge that the current economic situation is bad and proposes that funding more intellectual garbage like he spews is that answer.  I am sure that would improve his personal economy, but see no reason to believe it would do anything on a macro level.  If the professor stopped gazing at his navel, I doubt that he would have anything valuable to contribute to the current malaise.  He seems to be educated in a field that prides itself on its lack of practical application.  Why are the Stone articles so consistently inconsequential?

Greg, US:

So people who don't like to be frisked should be considered suspicious?

Determining things like various applicable local tax rates would be an easy accomplishment for a database look-up program.  If such a program does not already exist, the state governments, which will gain billions in sales tax revenues, have plenty of incentive to create one (or to reward some enterprising Silicon Valley software company for developing one) and to ensure that it is updated as necessary.  If no such product currently exists, please let me know on the hush-hush so that I can line up the investors, hire the software engineers, and become a full-fledged member of the 1%.

Caveat, dental hygienists are not dentists and regardless of length of time are still not the dentist. However, in this case it sounded like she may have been right especially since the second dentist referred you to a specialist for a consult. You found a good one!
Regarding the hygienist, it is probably difficult for her to see recommendations made that fly in the face of her experience. Yes, dentists make a living off of their profession but if you are as busy as you can be and as efficient as you can be without sacrificing quality, you will make a good living without having to resort to only high cost and possibly unnecessary options.
Dr "G"- retired pediatric dentist
A pilot isn't an airline mechanic, but I'm willing to trust their judgement about an aircraft's airworthiness.  Anyone who flies commercially makes this trust judgement every single flight they take.

I moved to a new town a few years ago,  had an incident where a crown came loose, had to go to a new dentist in a strange city. She was on my insurance and closest to the place I lived. Hygienist took full mouth x-rays, told me that she did not see anything wrong with the tooth or root canal under the crown;  cement had worked loose after ten years and just needed re-cementing. Dentist came in, looked at x-rays and started poking at the uncovered tooth, shaking her head and saying "No-No, it needs to be extracted and an implant put in or we can do a new crown with a bridge to the other teeth" blah blah blah. I asked her why and she said "the tooth has been crowned for ten years and just weakened. That's common with crowns." After she left the hygienist looked at me and shrugged. She said "I'm sorry. I didn't see anything on the x-ray and I've been a dental  hygienist for 25 years." I got a second opinion and went to another dentist who x-rayed, examined and said there was absolutely no reason for tooth to be extracted and teeth were healthy around it.. She also sent me to an endodontist who x-rayed, pulp tested the tooth and the teeth around it. His diagnosis was that it was fine and suggested I find another dentist. I did. I had the crown re-cemented, have a checkup every six months and have had no problems since. There are some dishonest dentists out there and you have to remember they are just human too and also in the business to make money. GET A SECOND OPINION!!!

Tardive Dyskenesia can occur with the newer antipsychotics- more often Risperdal than Seroquel. I would advise that particularly for elders that the benzodiazpimes ( Ativan/Lorazepam, Xanax/Alprazolam, Klonopin - most common) or sleeping pills Restoril, Halcion, Ambien- be avoided. If there are sleep problems or mood problems, SOME of the SSRIs are the most gentle to address the problem.

See http://elderconsult.com/medications/

for a Geriatricians view on the benefits and risks ( written in English not medicalese) of the more common psychoactive medications for elders.
